text: Welcome back, everybody. Sorry for the prolonged adjournment there. Time sort of got away on us all. So we're moving now into the deliberation phase. Actually, Andrew Brown, you have your hand up. Did you want to say something? Yeah, I do, Chair, actually.
speaker: Unknown

text: I've sat through this morning quite quietly, but with great interest.  But look, I'd just like to remind us all, I hope it's appropriate, that we're dealing with a strategy that informs our plans, as in the next long-term plan and beyond. And we shouldn't get lost in the detail. And quite frankly, even the third bridge is a detail. The Te Aumutu bypass is a detail. What we need to be looking at is,  Does the strategy allow us to make a plan that is sensible when we are doing our next long-term plan? It's not about whether it's including a long-term, a third bridge. It's about whether it's the strategic direction going forward is catered for by this plan. And I'd like to say, I think Kirstie and Brian and their teams have done a fabulous job on this.  It's exactly what we need. The other comment I've got to make is we're all struggling to get our heads around what transportation, particularly for private individuals, is going to look like, perhaps in as short a space of time as five or 10 years. If we're going to meet our Paris Accord obligations, it's likely to be pretty different to what it is now.  Yeah, so that's just my starter for 10. I'll have more comments to make later, I have no doubt. Thanks.
speaker: andreewilten

text: Yeah, look, well put, Andrew. We do have to remind ourselves that this is a very high-level document, and it is something that has gone through a pretty robust process. I'm not too concerned about whether people think that there might be slight typographical errors. I'm sure those will be picked up in the fullness of time, but I'm more concerned about whether we're comfortable with the general flavour of the responses that we are giving to people who have taken the effort to submit to us  And in many instances, we've actually accommodated their suggestions around changes to our draft strategy. And that, dare I say, has been acknowledged by a number of submitters today to our credit.
